I don't know if there's a standard way to do this – just make sure that if someone (like a company you're interviewing with) asks how you calculated your GPA, you have some reasonable explanation


-----


At least with what I've seen with graduate school applications, major GPA is all classes in your major/specialization (lower/upper division/graduate), with slight exceptions where it makes sense. For example, if you're in EECS but specialize in pure EE (like circuit design), you wouldn't put in CS 61A/B/C. However, if you're in EECS but specialize in firmware, you can include the 61 series. Like mentioned above, make sure your rationale makes sense for whatever position/industry you're targeting. Anything beyond "cumulative GPA" doesn't have a firm definition, so it's up to you to make sure you're properly portraying your abilities to your target audience. 


I've personally never seen upper-division GPA, and I personally wouldn't recommend it (not all colleges have a clear distinction between "lower" and "upper" divisions).


Overall, though, I haven't seen any recruiters actually recommend this approach unless your cumulative GPA is below a 3.0 or so. 3.5+ is good regardless, but above that baseline recruiters tend to look more at experience and passion while GPA sees diminishing returns.

I wouldn't put both on your resume, unless explicitly asked for by an employer (which I've never seen happen, personally) or if you had a borderline GPA (~3.0) and your major GPA is significantly better than your cumulative GPA. As I mentioned in the student answer, you typically see diminishing returns after that borderline. Better GPA's are better, of course, but remember that recruiters will spend ~10 seconds on your resume as a whole - better to emphasize your experience and avoid vague terminology if not needed.

As a side note, since I think I missed your original point, NEVER put your technical GPA only and leave out your cumulative GPA (unless explicitly asked to do that, which I personally haven't seen done anywhere but graduate school applications). I've seen a recruiter laugh and nearly instantly dismiss a resume when he saw someone do that - nobody cares if you got an A- or B in a few classes, so long as your GPA isn't terrible/borderline and you have experience doing the type of work they'll want you to do.
Wait. Wouldn’t the cumulative gpa be misleading if it’s like 0.3 lower than the technical GPA?

Depends which 0.3 range you're talking about. If you're talking about 3.7 vs. 4.0, which is closer to the OP's situation, I can't say it'll make a huge difference. 3.7 isn't a bad GPA, and for most employers it should be enough to merit them looking through the rest of your application. It's not misleading to just list your cumulative GPA (after all, they're hiring you as an individual, not just as an EE or CS machine), it's less misleading but longer to list both major and cumulative GPA, and it's downright deceptive to only list major and not mark it as your major GPA. As I mentioned earlier, it's also not a great idea to only list major GPA and mark it as such - it implies your cumulative GPA is terrible, and they'll assume it's much worse than the 0.3 difference it actually is.

That said, it's ultimately everyone's individual choice. If you're near a borderline, like 3.2 major and 2.9 cumulative, it might be a good option to put both GPA's on your resume so you can hopefully pass any hard GPA cutoffs a company might set.
Is it ok to just write technical gpa (without notating it as technical) on resume? I have 4.0 technical 3.95 cumulative, but it's really awkward to differentiate between the two on paper.

history.content:
When I'm looking at resume template/ resume posted publicly on fellow CS students' website/LinkedIn, I notice that some ppl also include "Major GPA" or "Upper-division GPA" in addition to the regular one (and of course those are usually higher than the regular one, like 3.8ish regular one, almost 4.0 for the other)

I guess it's just a way to "compensate" some bad grades, and I do have one lower division class that really drags down my overall GPA... 

How do we usually calculate major GPA here? All CS requirements? 5 upper div + 2 major elective?

Also, is it advisable at all to do something like this? It seems to draw too much attention like you are trying hard to get away something, but maybe it really does let the reviewer realize something valuable here?

Any advice would be appreciated! Thanks a lot!
